title: Premier Horgan pledges province's capital plan to help boost value-added timber manufacturing
text:
Premier John Horgan says B.C.’s capital plan will “make sure that B.C.’s timber products are manufactured in Victoria, B.C.” — one of the last concrete locations from where the growing value-added timber industry could be created. In a statement on Saturday, Horgan announced that his government will introduce legislation this year to ensure the province’s planned project to put construction value-added timber on the table for B.C.’s 35,000 Indigenous people will be done in Victoria. The minister responsible for Crown corporations told Postmedia on Friday that it will be a challenge to ensure the proposed value-added timber project — and other units — will be built in Ontario or Quebec, or elsewhere in Canada. According to Horgan, another challenge is that the province will not be able to see the prices paid for these forests and therefore can’t sell the wood to other buyers in the Okanagan. “So we have to make sure that B.C. does not see the value-added wood being done in Ontario or Quebec,” said Horgan, who did not say how much the province will contribute to the funding. The New Democrats’ $300-million investment in B.C.’s timber industry will be part of B.C.’s Project WA Impact, which was unveiled last October. It will go towards rebuilding barriers for Indigenous people, encouraging Indigenous companies to create new businesses and foster a trade and labour relationship with Atlantic Canada. The cabinet is also expected to announce $30 million in matching funds for Indigenous municipalities. “I need to say that this is a new investment that is welcome news,” said Dr. Tony Grossi, B.C.’s director of Economic and Agricultural Development. Grossi told Postmedia on Saturday that the 10,000 jobs in the value-added forestry sector predicted in B.C. is being hit especially hard by the labour crisis. “For the rest of the province, it’s going to be awful difficult,” he said, referring to construction workers and ship workers employed in the valley. “It’s very hard for B.C.’s forestry sector to make its case to win trade.”
The B.C. Forest Industries Association — responsible for 90 per cent of B.C.’s world market value-added forestry — told Postmedia that under the initiative announced Friday, producers will now have a say on the price that is awarded to them for wood. Grossi said for the first time, B.C.’s 50,000 Indigenous people will be able to explore jobs opportunities in those other wood trade regions, since another opportunity they will have is to join up with American workers and work on an investment strategy in Canada to create jobs in forestry. “This is big, so we want to be part of the solution,” he said. First Nations leaders also welcomed the news, with Carla Bruni-Sinoussi, chief executive of the NFB First Nations Wits Halluw Ha’ in Paynesville, B.C., saying that it’s crucial that residential school survivors be given direct representation in the creation of the new timber policy. She said the experience of working with First Nations does mean that the importance of their inclusion will be respected by all stakeholders. “The government’s decision … makes a very big difference, because it will hopefully help to promote our community in the new project,” Bruni-Sinoussi said, noting it also means, for example, that the North Shore Indigenous Shop Assistants are included in the policy. Loren and Linda Arian of the council in Okanagan Falls welcomed the announcement, saying that although not all of the municipality’s 100,000 residents will be able to join the recreational communities of the Wood’s Nest Lake development, the news means well for the community’s economic development. “It’s great news that the province is really going to be working in partnership with us in the area of recreation,” Linda Arian said. Nelson Jennison, chair of the Okanagan Shuswap First Nation, said he couldn’t speak more highly of the province’s decision to include his community and that the government should be commended for supporting it on a public platform. “It’s not a project that should have been done with no consultation, but I just want to thank the Ministry of Agriculture for that,” he said.
